awd_titl_txt: RUI: Collaboration to Enhance Participation of Minority and Undergraduate Students in Nuclear Science
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports a collaborative nuclear physics research program that will further our knowledge of nuclides with high ratios of neutrons to protons, which are interesting because they exhibit behavior not observed in stable nuclides.  Experiments will be carried out at the National Superconducting Cyclotron Laboratory (NSCL) and be "day-one" ready for the upcoming Facility for Rare Isotope Beams when construction is complete.   The experiments include: investigating heavy nuclei in excited states shortly before they fragment, exploring and characterizing particular states of beryllium nuclei, measuring separation energies of excited states of magnesium, as well as research and development of a new particle detector.  Undergraduate and graduate students will collaborate with faculty at several US institutions to further this work and learn valuable highly technical skills. The projects will be evaluated through peer review and disseminated through presentations at national conferences, Ph.D. theses, and journal articles.

The PIs of this award are members of the MoNA-LISA collaboration, and the experiments they have planned will exploit the capabilities of the equipment that was developed at NSCL by the collaboration (a modular neutron array and a large area scintillation array).  Neutron-rich nuclides are very short-lived and decay by prompt neutron emission, making the MoNA-LISA system the ideal tool to investigate these nuclei.  Projects include analyzing data, implementing novel techniques to identify better and resolve isomeric nuclear states, measuring neutron-unbound states in neutron-rich nuclei, characterizing pre-fragmentation dynamics after relativistic beams interact with targets, as well as research and development toward a new gas electron multiplier based segmented target.  Future experiments focus on higher Z nuclides that are possible with the current experimental setup.  The students will learn valuable skills utilized in all facets of research including detector construction, data collection and analysis, and dissemination.

por.por_cntn:
The undergraduates at Wabash College in nuclear physics research supported by this grant helped to study neutron-rich nuclides, developing new methods to improve the calibration of MoNA-LISA system through automation and improve computational modeling within the collaboration. The MoNA (Modular Neutron Array) collaboration is comprised of several undergraduate college and Michigan State University. This work had significant impacts on the students’ career goals with five of six attending graduate programs in engineering, physics, and computer science. The weekly video conferences between collaborating institutions helped to support collaborative work between three undergraduate institutions and one historically black college institution. This led to an increased participation in nuclear physics among underrepresented groups and fostered greater connection between multiple institutions.

 

The intellectual merit of this their work includes advancing the collaboration's methods for detector calibration. The particular improvements involved using cosmic ray paths through the detector array to determine the relative offsets of each detector in time due to cable lengths and electronic latencies. By representing the array as a mathematical graph and connecting each pair sharing many hits in common a minimal error path could be determined. Such pairs are shown in the primary image. One minimal error path is shown as is a comparison of the offset determined automatically and by the the slower method previously used.

 

The broader impacts of this work included providing an opportunity for undergraduate students to participate in collaborative physics research. They gained experience in data-analysis, programming in C++ and Python, and working in diversre and disperesd teams. These skills and experiences helped them to pursue and succeed in graduate-level work in engineering, physics, and computer science.

Modified by: James A Brown
